Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Medical Devices for Real-time Radiation Dosimetry at Sub-millimeter Spatial Resolution
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project seeks development of a novel dosimeter for 2-D mapping of radiation dose in real-time at sub-millimeter spatial resolution. The high spatial resolution of the dosimeter is essential in supporting stereotactic radiosurgery (SRS) and stereotactic body radiation therapy (SBRT) treatments. These rapidly emerging modalities deliver precise doses of radiation to small, well defined treatment sites while minimizing exposure of critical neighboring anatomy. With the annual number of SRS/SBRT treatments approaching 1,000,000 and growing 5-10% annually there is a market need for a dosimeter with sub-millimeter resolution and the capability of measuring in real-time. The routine pre-treatment verification of each patient therapy plan becomes a target application. The value of the market for the dosimeter alone exceeds $10 million annually. The value is amplified through enablement of the safe and efficacious delivery of SRS and SBRT treatments. Use of these modalities greatly impacts the efficiency of radiotherapy by substantially reducing the number of individual sessions in a course of treatment. The net result is lower cost for the treatment course, an increase in the number of patients/year for each linear accelerator equipment unit and a large reported improvement in patient outcomes.

The intellectual merit of this project lies in combining and adapting key elements of two well-established commercial technologies, piezoelectric polymers and radiochromic film, to produce a hybrid dosimeter. This dosimeter preserves the high spatial resolution of radiochromic film while improving its usability by making the changes caused by radiation exposure to become detectable by electronic means in real-time. During use, the flexible, single-use piezoelectric array dosimeter (PARD) fits into a re-usable data acquisition electronics module that transmits a map of measured doses to a Medical Physicist outside the radiation cell. Radiochromic film, the only current dosimeter with sub-millimeter spatial resolution, is inconvenient owing to the long delay between exposure and measurement as well as the extra time and effort in facilitating the measurements. This drawback adversely impacts its usefulness in the day-to-day verification of patient treatment plans. The hybrid PARD product provides a dense, flexible array (0.1 mm spacing) of detectors with the unique ability for dose measurement at sub-millimeter resolution in real time. This overcomes key drawbacks of existing electronic array devices which are incapable of spatial resolution below 5 mm and unsuitable for the small radiation fields associated with SRs and SBRT treatments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The vision for this SBIR Phase 1 program has been the development of a novel dosimeter for 2-D mapping of radiation dose in real-time at sub-millimeter spatial resolution. This product will provide essential support to the administration of stereotactic radiosurgery (SRS) and stereotactic body radiation therapy (SBRT) treatments. The combination of high spatial resolution measurement in real time is not provided by current dosimeters. It is a combination that is critically important to support the design and validation of precise treatments involving high dose gradients needed in targeting treatment sites adjacent to critical organs and anatomy. Time is also of particular value in radiotherapy clinics as high patient throughput accentuates the need for measurement tools that provide immediate results.  Based on extensive discussions with Medical Physicists worldwide before and during the course of this work it is believed that this array dosimeter will be welcomed as it fills a performance gap where the available devices provide only one or the other. They can measure dose in real time, but only at 5 mm spatial resolution; or measure with at sub-millimeter resolution, but only with a delay of tens of minutes, or more, after the exposure to radiation.

The value of this combination of properties is amplified because it enables the safe and efficacious delivery of SRS and SBRT treatments.  Use of the SRS/SBRT modalities can make for greater efficiency since it can reduce the number of individual sessions in a course of treatment. At the same time the radiation dose per treatment is increased, making dose measurement at high spatial resolution more valuable in avoiding misadministration. By reducing the number of treatment sessions, the net result is lowered cost of treatment, an increase in the number of patients/year for each linear accelerator equipment unit and an improvement bio-effectiveness of the treatments.       

A principal objective of Phase 1 has been to demonstrate the novel idea of combining and adapting key elements of two well-established commercial technologies, piezoelectric polymers and radiochromic film, to produce a hybrid dosimeter. A second objective has been to examine the materials and processes that could be applied in manufacturing an array of such sensors efficiently and cost-effectively. Both immediate objectives were chosen in support of the commercial goal of a developing a radiation dosimeter to improve measurement capability in medical radiotherapy.

During the program radiation sensors were made by coating a formulation containing a selected diacetylene monomer on a commercially available piezoelectric polymer film to make sensors 2-3 mm2 in size. When exposed to ionizing radiation, we observed strong and definitive piezoelectric response up to and exceeding 4V. The electrical responses increased with increasing exposure and were measurable concurrent with the exposure. By altering the size of the sensor area in the range of about 1-4 mm2 no correlation between sensor size and sensor response was observed. Similar sensors exposed to 6MV photons from a linear accelerator, as commonly used in radiotherapy clinics, exhibited response up to about 400 mV for a radiation dose of about 100 cGy. Doses applied in during radiotherapy treatment are typically about 200 cGy, or greater. The measurements demonstrate that the diacetylene-based piezoelectric radiation sensors exhibit a suitable level of response for use in radiotherapy QA.

 

To demonstrate a path for efficient fabrication of a piezoelectric sensor array, work during Phase 1 demonstrated how commercially available conductive inks together with inks formulated from commercially available piezoelectric polymers could be printed and/or coated on a flexible substrate. These piezoelectric sensors were converted to radiation sensors by application of a diacetylene monomer formulation. Upon exposure of these radiation sensors to ionizing radiation it was demonstrated that the sensors had similar strong responses as those observed from the sensors using commercial piezoelectric polymer film.  

At the finish of the Phase 1 program a proof of concept had been demonstrated. This technical success supports the feasibility of developing a commercial 2D radiation dosimeter capable of sub-millimeter spatial resolution with measurement available in real time. Continued contact with Medical Physicists, who represent the future customer/user community, were maintained throughout the program. Their positive reaction to learning of progress during Phase 1 continues to support the need for the technology under development and that a real-time dosimeter with sub-millimeter spatial resolution would be a welcome and needed addition to a Medical Physicist’s tool list.
